summary.p: The bundle contains two works attributed to Auvaiyār: the Ātticūṭi (complete) and the Koṉṟaivēntāṉ (complete). Both are named Nīticcol ("moral maxims") in the manuscript. These works are often used for learning the Tamil alphabet as the aphorisms are ordered alphabetically and represent all the letters of the Tamil alphabet. The bundle is possibly a school exercise. The lay-out of the page is in columns for the mūlam.

origin.origDate: No internal date. Ca 1845 according to Vinson (1867-1896, p. 21), 1845 according to Cabaton (1912, p. 54). The reason for this date is unknown.

encodingDesc.p: Abbreviations. c = column, f = folio, lm = left margin, r = recto, rm = right margin,U = unit (codicological and/or textual), v = verso.

Transliteration conventions. Unmarked puḷḷi, ō, and ē restored. Conjectural (whether the text is notclearly legible or the character is ambigous, e.g. kāl or length of o and e) readings between parentheses. Alternative readings between parentheses separated by slash. Lost or entirely illegible character: "?". Crossed-out character: "X". Conjectural restoration of lost or entirely illegible between square brackets. Uppercase for initial vowels (in excerpts only). Unquoted text represented by (...). Conjunct letter: e.g. t°, to be read tum or tam. Grantha letters in bold. Symbols/Abbreviations made explicit, between curly brackets: {pcs} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, short form; {pcl} = piḷḷaiyār cuḻi, long form, that is, with long horizontal stroke towards right; {varuṣam}, {mācam}, {tēti}; {line-filler}. Unfoliated folio number between square brackets, e.g. "f[1]r". Numerals normalised to decimal notation, e.g. "1121" not "1000 1 100 2 10 1". Hyphen occasionaly used to mark in-word components. Hyphen systematically used at the end of a line when the line-beginning is within a word or within a cīr. Sandhi split to the minimum: overshort u occasionally restored as an apostrophe. Stanzas split by cīr, as far as possible.aṭi boundary marked by "‡".
